title: 103_s857
content: The Act titled as the "National Commission To Ensure Small Aircraft Safety Act of 1993" is established to ensure small aircraft safety. Congress declares small aircraft safety as a national concern and emphasizes the need for Federal Government resources to ensure safety. The National Transportation Safety Board urged the Federal Aviation Administration to conduct full fleet inspections of Hartzell propeller assemblies after an accident, but the FAA concluded that a special investigation was not necessary, leading to dissatisfaction from the NTSB. The National Transportation Safety Board urges the Federal Aviation Administration to address small aircraft safety issues and establish procedures to resolve disagreements among Federal agencies regarding aircraft safety. Resolving government gridlock in ensuring the safety of pilots and passengers is crucial. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION. Establishment of the National Commission To Ensure Small Aircraft Safety with 11 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives. The National Commission To Ensure Small Aircraft Safety will consist of 11 members appointed by the President, Senate, and House of Representatives. The appointments must be made within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. Members will serve for the life of the Commission, and any vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. The Commission, once all members are appointed, will hold its first meeting. Meetings will be called by the Chairman, and a majority of members will constitute a quorum. Members must be experts in general aviation policy, small aircraft safety, and represent various organizations. The Commission will select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from its members. The Commission's duties are outlined in Section 4. The Commission will study current investigatory procedures and practices of the National Transportation Safety Board and the Federal Aviation Administration regarding small aircraft safety. It will also develop recommendations to achieve a national goal of safety in small aircraft and the general aviation industry. The Commission will study and resolve disagreements among Federal agencies responsible for small aircraft safety, develop coordination, and ensure enforcement of safety regulations. A report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations will be submitted to the President and Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Commission's personnel matters are addressed in Section 6 of the Act. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as federal government officers or employees. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided at authorized rates for agency employees. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Chairman can also determine their compensation without adhering to specific regulations regarding pay rates and position classification. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. The pay rates for the executive director and other personnel cannot exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will end 180 days after submitting its report. All records will be archived. $______ is authorized for the Commission in 1994, with funds available indefinitely.
